metadata.title: COVID-19 Twitter Dataset with Latent Topics, Sentiments and Emotions Attributes COVID-19 Twitter Dataset with Latent Topics, Sentiments and Emotions Attributes

abstract.text: This resource paper describes a large dataset covering over 63 million coronavirus-related Twitter posts from more than 13 million unique users since 28 January to 1 July 2020. As strong concerns and emotions are expressed in the tweets, we analyzed the tweets content using natural language processing techniques and machine-learning based algorithms, and inferred seventeen latent semantic attributes associated with each tweet, including 1) ten attributes indicating the tweet's relevance to ten detected topics, 2) five quantitative attributes indicating the degree of intensity in the valence (i.e., unpleasantness/pleasantness) and emotional intensities across four primary emotions of fear, anger, sadness and joy, and 3) two qualitative attributes indicating the sentiment category and the most dominant emotion category, respectively. To illustrate how the dataset can be used, we present descriptive statistics around the topics, sentiments and emotions attributes and their temporal distributions, and discuss possible applications in communication, psychology, public health, economics and epidemiology.

body_text.text: The 2019 coronavirus disease was first officially reported as acute respiratory infections caused by an unknown virus in Wuhan city, Hubei province in China on 31 December 2019. To date, the disease has infected 10,357,662 people worldwide and claimed 508,055 lives, according to the World Health Organization (WHO)'s situation report as at 1 July 2020 (WHO, 2020) .

The issues surrounding the pandemic are increasingly challenging and complex. The complexity not only comes from the disease itself, but also by the surge of the medical, social, behavioural and economic issues that the disease has been surrounded with, such as reports on daily counts of new cases and mortality rates, scientific discoveries, government responses, news reporting of social behaviours such as panic buying and food hoarding, impact on businesses and economic outlook, and changes in people's everyday lives. The challenges are multi-faceted and unprecedented. There is a growing recognition of the need for multidisciplinary research efforts to support the COVID-19 pandemic response, including disciplines such as social and behavioural science (Bavel et al., 2020) and mental health science (Holmes et al., 2020) .

Twitter is a popular microblogging site widely used by Internet users. According to Statista, as of the fourth quarter of 2019, Twitter had 152 million active users worldwide (Statista, 2020) . Twitter provides the research community a rich source of information about when, where and what people have to say in their posts (known as "tweets") through its free, publicly accessible Application Programming Interface (API) service. However, the raw tweet content is mostly in textual format and is not readily analysable. When there is a huge amount of tweets, it takes a significant amount of time to accurately extract information related to people's concerns, feelings and emotions for human analysts and researchers to process and analyse for in-depth patterns and insights.

The dataset described in our resource paper provides tweet-by-tweet tagging of the topic clusters that a tweet is semantically related to, the sentiment it is expressing, and the emotional properties it is associated with. Despite the fact that Twitter have opened up realtime, full-fidelity data streams related to COVID-19 tweets since late April 2020 (Twitter, 2020) , and that there has been a few recent studies (e.g., Abd-Alrazaq et al., 2020; Budhwani and Sun 2020) including our rapid report (Lwin et al., 2020) which provided early insights using Twitter data to study , to the best of our knowledge, no other studies have provided such a tweet-by-tweet research resource with rich and semantically meaningful attributes surrounding the topics, sentiments and emotions from the tweets content.

Our objective is to make this new dataset available for the broader research communities to perform in-depth investigations in all possible areas such as discovering the correlational patterns between the psychologically meaningful information provided with other important variables such as government policy communications, demographics, economic indicators, as well as epidemiological markers.

As at 1 July 2020, our system has collected a total of 63,347,100 English tweets worldwide using the four COVID-19 related keywords, with the first retrievable date being 28 January 2020. These tweets are posted by 13,749,346 unique users based on the user_ID attribute. Table 1 presents the data overview. Out of all the tweets, majority are retrieved based on the "covid" keyword which returned 44,930,122 tweets, or 71%. On average, 17,029 COVID-related tweets were posted every hour, or 408,691 tweets every day.

The following shows the list of top ten topic clusters detected in the dataset and their most associated words, respectively. We checked the tweets volume related to the top ten identified topic clusters. A vast majority of tweets are related to two or more topics, which form 60% of the total tweets. The tweets that solely pertain to topic_1 have the highest volume, consisting of 14,467,272 tweets or 23% out of the total data volume. Table 2 presents the overall tweet topics statistics. Figure 1 depicts with a visualization of the topic clusters in the context of the tweets volume.

The quantitative sentiment intensity score averaged for the full dataset is 0.460, with the most negative tweet having its valence intensity score of -0.058, and the most positive tweet having its valence intensity score of 0.989 (Table 3) . Qualitatively, the counts and distributions for valence intensity score converted into sentiment categories counts are presented in Figure 3 . The results indicate that the majority of the tweets are "Negative" or "Very Negative", forming 58% of the total 63,347,100 tweets.
body_text.section: Sentiments, and sentiment distribution by time

body_text.text: Plotting the sentiment categories over daily aggregated tweets counts suggested more nuanced patterns (see Figure 3 ). For example, the single-day peak during this period was 1,075,087 tweets (629,938 were "Negative" tweets and 65,165 were "Very Negative" tweets), which took place on 13 March 2020, one day immediately following WHO's announcement on the disease as a "pandemic". Further research may look into, for example, the sentiment change before and after more targeted time periods based on critical announcements (e.g., to study a week before and after 12 March 2020). The dataset may also allow for further research to explore the correlations and predictive values based on the sentiment and emotion scores, when over-laid with economic indicators (e.g., stock market changes).
body_text.section: Figure 2. Five sentiment categories tweets count and distribution

body_text.text: Using the four quantitative emotions intensities attributes, overall statistics show that fear intensity score has the highest mean value of 0.440, closely followed by anger intensity score of 0.437. Table 5 reports the descriptive statistics for the four emotions intensity scores. Qualitatively, the counts and distribution of the various most dominant emotion categories are presented in Figure 4 . The results suggest that, over the five months in total, tweets that are dominantly expressing anger (16,864,419 tweets, 27%) and tweets that are dominantly expressing fear (16,668,156 tweets, 26%) formed the majority of the total tweets.
body_text.section: Emotions and emotions distribution by time

body_text.text: WHO announces the COVID-19 outbreak as a "pandemic" (12 March 2020)
body_text.section: Emotions and emotions distribution by time

body_text.text: We plotted the daily counts of the four emotions for the five-month period (see Figure 5 ). The trends surfaced some interesting patterns: While both fear and anger dominated in the overall counts, the trend plot shows that over time, the relative distribution of fear has been decreasing and the relative distribution of anger has been increasing; meanwhile, joy and other positive expressions have been increasing, though in a slower rate (See Lwin et al., 2020 which provides an early report and interpretation of this observation in more details).
body_text.section: Figure 4. Count of tweets and distribution of each dominant emotion category

body_text.text: The significance of the change can be illustrated using the contrast of results at the start and at the end of our data range. For example, as at 28 January 2020, a total of 23,405 tweets were posted for the day, and the tweets with anger as the most dominant emotion formed 15% of the total 23,405 tweets, far less than those tweets with fear as the most dominant emotion which formed 53% of the total 23,405 tweets. In contrast, as at 1 July 2020, a total of 432,736 total tweets were posted for the day, and the tweets with anger as the most dominant No specific emotion 10,327,571, 16%
body_text.section: Figure 5. Daily distribution of the four primary emotions over time

body_text.text: 1 July 2020 28 January 2020 emotion formed 30% of the 432,736 tweets, exceeding those tweets with fear as the most dominant emotion, which formed 23% of the 432,736 tweets).
body_text.section: Figure 5. Daily distribution of the four primary emotions over time

body_text.text: Leveraging the present dataset, we propose that the research community may further examine the anger trend, and future research could be conducted to investigate the correlations between the emotions trends and other indicators, such as those from epidemiological data streams, economic indicators, as well as survey-based findings.
body_text.section: Figure 5. Daily distribution of the four primary emotions over time

body_text.text: This paper presents a new COVID-19 tweets dataset with additional, psychologically meaningful attributes. This tagged Twitter dataset may create new opportunities to understand both global and local conversations and social sentiments in real time, at a large scale, potentially leading to very rich insights on human behaviours and behavioural changes.

Based on the richness and granularity of this dataset, we envisage its potential applications in five broad areas. First, for media and mass communication research, the dataset can be useful for communication scientists and professionals to consider in terms of evaluating and improving government response, policies and media communications towards the unprecedented pandemic crisis. For example, a recent study compared communications efforts of health authorities in the United States, the United Kingdom and Singapore on Facebook during the early period of COVID-19 (Raamkumar et al., 2020). As the virus has continuously hit different countries in different timeframes and governments implemented different response strategies and policies, one direction of an ongoing related work is to overlay the location attribute, examine and compare sentiments, emotions and topics associated with different countries (e.g., see Lwin et al., 2020b) . The dataset may also help to study how media's topical and emotional framing in their headlines and titles are different from those expressed by the general public.

Second, the dataset is of interest for psychology research. The granularity of the tweets metadata in terms of tweet_created_at and user_ID may allow researchers to dive deeper of the more nuanced trends with deeper psychological accounts and insights. One possibility is to look into the sentiments and emotions differences over more fine-grained timelines, examine more targeted sub-topics, cultural differences, and segregate the users which are influencers vs the general public. Future research may also look into leveraging user characteristics inference techniques (e.g., Volkova et al., 2015) and the present dataset to investigate user community-specific tendencies and issues.

Third, as the pandemic escalates in its severity and geographical span, and is likely to last for a prolonged period, public mental health issues (e.g., Luo et al., 2020 ) are more prevalent. The dataset may be used to examine public mental health and emotional wellbeing. Prior literature (e.g., Ohman 2008; Karp, 2017) has established the conceptual linkages between fear (as an emotion) and anxiety (as a mental disorder), and between sadness (as an emotion category) and depression (as a mental disorder). Hence it can be fruitful to study the value of the emotion intensity scores and their trends in the context of its duration, frequency and in relation to various user communities.

Fourth, it is potentially useful to overlay publicly available economic indicators (e.g., daily stock market data, monthly unemployment rates reports), and investigate in more depth on how the twitter topics, sentiments and emotions trends are correlated or present predictive value in future research.

Last but not least, data scientists and epidemiology researchers may find the dataset useful. For example, prior research in Zika and dengue outbreaks have studied and found useful insights in overlaying with air travel networks and virus genome (Grubaugh et al., 2019; Nunes et al., 2014; Tatem et al., 2012) . Hence the dataset may contribute towards revealing more hidden patterns and relationships of the large-scale social media content and other pandemic-related data streams.

In this section, we describe the methods behind the data collection and data processing with a focused interest on tracking and understanding topics, social sentiments and emotions surrounding the COVID-19 pandemic. Specifically, we applied natural language processing (NLP) techniques, in particular, statistical topic clustering techniques that detect tweets surrounding similar topic clusters. We also applied previously machine learning-trained and validated algorithms to tag each tweet with a sentiment valence (unpleasantness / pleasantness), as well as intensity scores of four different emotionsanger, fear, sadness and joy.

We started to set up our data collection app on early February 2020 by querying Twitter's standard search API 1 using three keywords "corona", "wuhan" (many people refer to the virus as "wuhan virus" at initial stages when official names were not yet announced), and "ncov" (WHO first named the virus as "2019-ncov"). On 11 February 2020, upon WHO officially renamed the disease as "COVID-19", we added "covid" as a new search keyword. Simple sharing of these tweets (i.e., retweets) are not collected for the dataset.

The API returns the tweet content with a rich range of attributes. For example, we were able to download the following 12 attributes in our database 2 . Table 6 illustrates the downloaded attributes with a tweet example.

 tweet_ID: The unique identifier for this tweet  tweet_created_at: The UTC time when this tweet was created  text: The actual UTF-8 text of the tweet  retweet_count: Number of times this tweet has been retweeted  favorite_count: Number of times this tweet has been liked  hashtag_text: Name of the hashtag, minus the leading '#' character  user_ID: The unique identifier for the user who created the tweet  location: The user-defined location in this account's profile  followers_count: Number of followers this account currently has  friends_count: Number of users this account is following  statuses_count: Number of tweets (including retweets) issued by the user  user_created_at: The UTC datetime that the user account was created on Twitter In compliance with Twitter's content redistribution terms, the Twitter data in our released dataset only includes the tweet_ID attribute. Users shall use tweet_ ID to retrieve the other attributes through the standard search API from Twitter.

It is useful to note that a known limitation of Twitter's standard search API is that it does not guarantee the retrieved tweets are exhaustive or complete. In other words, it retrieves relevant but not all the tweets that match the search keywords.

Although all the retrieved tweets are relevant to at least one of the four COVID-19 related keywords, there are many facets or subtopics people have covered in the tweets' text content. We applied an unsupervised topic clustering technique called Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA) to facilitate the understanding of the subtopics. LDA is a probabilistic generative model which learns a multinomial distributions of latent topics in a given document and words in a given topic (Blei et al., 2003) . The advantage of LDA is that it is independent of the corpus size which makes it algorithmically efficient to learn topic clusters within a corpus with a large number of tweets such as ours.

First, we pre-processed each raw tweet by converting it to ASCII characters, removing accented characters, forming bigrams and trigrams, filtering out stopwords (including most rare and most frequent words), and performing text tokenization. These pre-processed tweets were then converted into a bag-of-words (BoW) corpus. The training data's date range is 28 January to 27 May 2020, which consists of 51 million tweets. Next, we randomly sampled 1% of the BoW corpus and trained an LDA model whose inference was performed using online variational Bayes (Hoffman et al. 2010 ). The quality of the topic model was evaluated using metrics including perplexity and coherence scores (Chang et al. 2009 ). Lastly, for each tweet in the dataset, we assigned a relevance label ("1" or "0") based on its contribution to the document ('1' if contribution > 0.01 or 1/number of topics).

We obtained the top ten topics that received a relatively high coherence scores (c_v measure, mean = 0.575) from a model optimized by learning 100 topics and hyper-parameters α as a fixed normalized asymmetric Dirichlet prior (1/topic_number) and η = 0.909. Table 7 shows example tweets that are tagged with the corresponding topic clusters that they are relevant to, respectively. The first ten examples show tweets that are solely relevant to each of the ten topic clusters. The last example shows that a tweet can be relevant to multiple topic clusters simultaneously. It is useful to note that we obtained ten topics out of 100 extracted from 500,000-odd data points, which is a 1% sample from the full dataset, due to the high computational cost in using even larger samples. Our aim here is to apply NLP techniques and demonstrate how sub-topics detected from the full data could help to gauge some important aspects of COVID-19 conversations in social media. Conceivably, a larger sample could represent the topics better, and as a future work, we could use a bigger sample (10%). On the other hand, training an LDA model with data from specific twitter accounts, smaller and more focused date range, particular countries of interest, or certain hashtags, would yield more targeted and meaningful results. Hence, another future extension is to package the topic modelling software with the dataset to help researchers with seamless fine-grained topic tagging.

As sentiments and emotions are subjective information embedded in the unstructured text content, it is a necessity to extract such information with targeted tools. We used CrystalFeel, a collection of five machine-learning trained algorithms to extract the sentiment and emotions scores, which had features including affective lexicons, parts-of-speech, n-grams, and word embeddings (Gupta and Yang 2018) trained using tweets manually annotated with intensity ground truth values (Mohammed and Bravo-Marquez, 2017; Mohammed et al., 2018) .
body_text.section: Sentiment valence and emotions intensity scores attributes inference

body_text.text: As reported in Gupta and Yang (2018) 's evaluation experiments, the CrystalFeel algorithms' accuracies in terms of Pearson correlation coefficient (r) is 0.816 on valence intensity, and are 0.708, 0.740, 0.700 and 0.720 on joy intensity, anger intensity, fear intensity and sadness intensity 3 . The predictive validity of the valence, joy, anger, fear and sadness intensity scores on other NLP tasks has also been studied and demonstrated in the context of predicting news social popularity , in predicting the ingredients of happy moments , and in detecting propaganda techniques in news articles (Krishnamurthy et al., 2020) .
body_text.section: Sentiment valence and emotions intensity scores attributes inference

body_text.text: Hence, each tweet in the dataset is tagged with the following five attributes related to the sentiment valence and emotions intensity scores.
body_text.section: Sentiment valence and emotions intensity scores attributes inference

body_text.text:  valence_intensity_score: A real-valued score with its normal range as from 0 to 1, where 0 -this text expresses highest possible intensity of unpleasant feelings; 1 -this text expresses highest possible intensity of pleasant feelings  anger_intensity_score: A real-valued score with its normal range as from 0 to 1, where 0 -this text expresses lowest possible intensity of anger; 1 -this text expresses highest possible intensity of anger  fear_intensity_score: A real-valued score with its normal range as from 0 to 1, where 0 -this text expresses lowest possible intensity of fear; 1 -this text expresses highest possible intensity of sadness  sadness_intensity_score: A real-valued score with its normal range as from 0 to 1, where 0 -this text expresses lowest possible intensity of sadness; 1 -this text expresses highest possible intensity of sadness  joy_intensity_score: A real-valued score with its normal range as from 0 to 1, where 0 -this text expresses lowest possible intensity of joy; 1 -this text expresses highest possible intensity of joy Table 8 shows five example tweets tagged with these five attributes. The first example shows a tweet with a moderate sentiment valence score (i.e., neither very negative nor very positive), and the other four examples show tweets with relatively high intensity score for joy, anger, fear and sadness dimensions. It shall be noted that, in certain cases such as the fourth example in Table 8 , the intensity score may be exceeding the [0, 1] normal ranges, which indicates that these cases represented extreme intensities beyond the algorithms' original training samples.
body_text.section: Sentiment valence and emotions intensity scores attributes inference

body_text.text: To facilitate more straightforward interpretation, we also converted CrystalFeel algorithm's sentiment valence intensity score (quantitative value as "valence_ intensity_score") into to a categorical label (qualitative value as "sentiment_category") using the following logic.

// # Initialize the sentiment category in a "neutral or mixed" class 1 sentiment_category = "neutral or mixed"; // # Assign the sentiment category based on the degree of the valence intensity 2 if(valence_intensity_score <= 0.30): 3 sentiment_category = "very negative"; 4 elif(valence_intensity_score < 0.48): 5 sentiment_category = "negative"; 6 elif(valence_intensity_score > 0.70): 7 sentiment_category = "very positive"; 8 elif(valence_intensity_score > 0.52): 9 sentiment_category = "positive"; Therefore, each tweet has an additional sentiment_category attribute. Table 9 shows the five tweets examples tagged with their corresponding sentiment categories, qualitatively indicating the sentiment each tweet is mainly expressing.
 sentiment_category: A categorical value indicating the sentiment a tweet is expressing, with a value being either "very negative", "negative", neutral or mixed", "positive", "very positive"

As the underlying dominant emotion behind the sentiments carries more information than the overall valence or sentiment, we also converted CrystalFeel's joy, anger, fear and sadness intensity scores into an emotion category value to facilitate interpretation.

To achieve this, we applied a logic that leverages all the valence and emotions intensities scores from CrystalFeel's outputs. We first use valence_intensity_score as the first-line criterion as this dimension that has very high accuracy, i.e., 0.816 in terms of Pearson correlation with human annotated ground truth values. We then use the relative intensity comparing the three primary negative emotions, anger, fear and sadness to assign a corresponding dominant emotion category. The following script describes the conversion logic: // # Initialize the sentiment category in a "no specific emotion" class 1 emotion_category = "no specific emotion"; // # Assign the emotion category when valence intensity score exceeds 0.52 2 if(valence_intensity_score > 0.52): 3 emotion_category = "joy or other positive expression"; // # Assign the emotion category when valence intensity score falls below 0.48 4 elif(valence_intensity_score < 0.48): 5 emotion_category = "anger"; 6 if((fear_intensity_score > anger_intensity_score) and (fear_intensity_score > = sadness_intensity_score )): 7 emotion_category = "fear"; 8 elif((sadness_intensity_score > anger_intensity_score) and sadness_intensity_score > fear_intensity_score)): 9 emotion_category = "sadness"; Therefore, each tweet has an additional emotion_category attribute, indicating the dominant emotion as detected in the tweet. Table 10 shows the five tweets examples tagged with the dominant emotion categories.

 emotion_category: A categorical value indicating the most dominant emotion a tweet is expressing, with a value being either "anger", "fear", "sadness", "joy or other positive expression", "no specific emotion" To any fellow nationalist celebrating boris getting the corona virus are nothing less than an absolute cunt.

anger Being higher risk of covid has me all over the place. Appt is in about 90 mins . Im scared , worried and anxious fear When u cant handle shit any longer and u feel hopeless #COVID_19 starting to make my depression worse sadness Seeing this face for just a few minutes on her 97th birthday today made my heart so happy! #Greatful #COVID #Nana joy or other positive expression Methodological note on score-to-category conversion for future research

The CrystalFeel algorithms' accuracy in determining valence, fear, anger, sadness and joy intensity scores are systematically validated in prior research (Gupta and Yang 2018) , and are subsequently tested for predictive validities in other NLP tasks Krishnamurthy et al., 2020) . It is recommended to examine the use of the sentiment and emotions intensity scores directly without conversions.

Meanwhile, the sentiment and emotion categories are obtained based on a conversion logic. The conversion principle that allows each tweet to be labelled with one of the five emotion categories (i.e., "fear", "anger", "sadness", "joy or other positive expression", "no specific emotion") follows a conceptual simplification that a dominant emotion exists for each tweet, though some tweets can express "mixed emotions" (Berrios et al. 2015) , such as express high fear-joy or high anger-sadness simultaneously.

Hence, we recommend that other conversion logic may be explored in future research. For example, Mohammad et al. (2018) suggest to use the mid-scale threshold, i.e., 0.5, to differentiate high-intensity vs. non-high-intensity anger, fear, sadness or joy emotions. The selection of the threshold should be considered based on the applications, for example, when using the sentiments and emotions as outcome variables or predictor variables.

back_matter.text: The authors thank Anita Sheldenkar, Brandon Loh Siyuan, Cui Mengyang, Gangeshwar Krishnamurthy, Lim Keng Hui, Jiahui Lu, May Oo Lwin, Nur Atiqah Othman, Paul E. Cain, Sebastian Maurer-Stroh, Therese Quieta, Thomas Vuong, Tuan Le Mau, Wan Kum Seong, Wong Chi Kit, and Zhang Mila, for helpful discussions. We are grateful for the help from Nur Atiqah Othman for her proofreading which helped to enhance the clarity of the paper. All errors that remain are our sole responsibility.

The authors declare the following competing interests: RG and YY are co-inventors of the CrystalFeel algorithm which was used to extract the sentiment and emotion attributes. No other conditions or circumstances present a potential conflict of or competing interest for the other authors.

The full dataset described in this paper is available for download at http://resources.socialanalyticsplus.net. We ran the topic models every month and will provide an update of the database at the start of each month. A live, hourly refreshed visualization dashboard is accessible via http://corona2019.socialanalyticsplus.net.
Interested readers may check our source scripts for processing the topic models at http://resources.socialanalyticsplus.net.

This work is supported by the Agency for Science, Technology and Research (A*STAR) under its A*ccelerate Gap Fund (ETPL/18-GAP050-R20A), the Singapore Ministry of Health's National Medical Research Council under its COVID-19 Research Fund (COVID19RF-005) and the Institute of High Performance Computing, A*STAR.

RG acquired the data and extracted sentiment and emotions features. AV extracted topic clusters features. YY initiated, conceptualized, and led the manuscript. All authors performed data analysis, contributed to the manuscript writing, reviewed the content and agreed with the submission.

The dataset is available as a .csv file with over 63 million tweet_IDs and their corresponding topics, sentiments and emotions attributes. It covers COVID-19 related English tweets posted by more than 13 million unique users since 28 January to 1 July 2020. The detailed technical description can be found here.Complete a simple registration to receive a link to download the dataset.
back_matter.section: Supplementary information Appendix A. The publicly available interface for downloading the dataset COVID-19 Twitter dataset with latent topics, sentiments and emotions attributes

back_matter.text: We processed over 63 million COVID related tweets' text content using natural language processing techniques and machine-learning based algorithms, which tags each tweet with additional attributes that are helpful to quantify the information about the tweet's topics, sentiments and emotions.This folder consists of the three files:1. tweets_topics_sentiments_emotions (5k sample).csv This is a very small, randomly selected sample of the full dataset. It can be used to quickly understand the data structure and attributes.
back_matter.section: Appendix B. Readme for using the dataset COVID-19 Twitter dataset with latent topics, sentiments and emotions attributes

back_matter.text: This is the full 63 million tweets csv file. The file is approximately 6 GB. It is recommended to use python+pandas to view and manipulate the document.There are a total of 19 columns: tweet_ID (the unique identifier for this tweet), the keywords we used to query the Twitter API, and the following 17 latent topics, sentiments and emotions attributes. 10) topic_10: A binary value of 0 or 1, where 0this tweet is not relevant to this topic; 1this tweet is relevant to this topic 11) valence_intensity_score: A real-valued score with its normal range as from 0 to 1, where 0 -this text expresses highest possible intensity of unpleasant feelings; 1 -this text expresses highest possible intensity of pleasant feelings 12) anger_intensity_score: A real-valued score with its normal range as from 0 to 1, where 0this text expresses lowest possible intensity of anger; 1 -this text expresses highest possible intensity of anger 13) fear_intensity_score: A real-valued score with its normal range as from 0 to 1, where 0this text expresses lowest possible intensity of fear; 1 -this text expresses highest possible intensity of sadness 14) sadness_intensity_score: A real-valued score with its normal range as from 0 to 1, where 0 -this text expresses lowest possible intensity of sadness; 1 -this text expresses highest possible intensity of sadness 15) joy_intensity_score: A real-valued score with its normal range as from 0 to 1, where 0this text expresses lowest possible intensity of joy; 1 -this text expresses highest possible intensity of joy 16) sentiment_category: A categorical value indicating the sentiment a tweet is expressing, with a value being either "very negative", "negative", neutral or mixed", "positive", "very positive" 17) emotion_category: A categorical value indicating the most dominant emotion a tweet is expressing, with a value being either "anger", "fear", "sadness", "joy or other positive expression", "no specific emotion" In compliance with Twitter's content redistribution terms, the Twitter data in our released dataset only includes the tweet_ID attribute. Users can use tweet_ ID to retrieve the other attributes (see examples below) through the standard search API from Twitter (https://developer.twitter.com/en/docs/tweets/search/overview/standard). tweet_ID: The unique identifier for this tweet  tweet_created_at: The UTC time when this tweet was created  text: The actual UTF-8 text of the tweet  retweet_count: Number of times this tweet has been retweeted  favorite_count: Number of times this tweet has been liked  hashtag_text: Name of the hashtag, minus the leading '#' character  user_ID: The unique identifier for the user who created the tweet  location: The user-defined location in this account's profile  followers_count: Number of followers this account currently has  friends_count: Number of users this account is following  statuses_count: Number of tweets (including retweets) issued by the user  user_created_at: The UTC datetime that the user account was created on Twitter 3. tweets dataset_gupta_vishwanath_yang.pdf This is the resource paper that describes the detailed data collection and processing methods. If you use this dataset and find it useful, please cite the source as: Gupta, R., Vishwanath, A., and Yang, Y. (2020) , COVID-19 Twitter dataset with latent topics, sentiments and emotions attributes, Working Manuscript, Institute of High Performance Computing

cite_spans.text: Gupta, R., Vishwanath, A., and Yang, Y. (2020)
